node.text: Results for the legend of zelda

The immersive gameplay that the others hint at is the beginning of the answer, but its not the whole story. Shigeru Miyamoto (lead designer) and Koji Kondo (composer) were able to use extremely limited digital resources to create a world that sucked you in, and yet sprawled for an eternity in every direction. The score, which ought to be heralded as the most epic in that hardware generation, immediately portrays a struggle that is greater than your 12 pixel avatar. The cave in the upper left corner beckons immediately - a siren call that will repeat throughout the game. And with every shifting square, with every changing background, a world unravels in front of you, full of danger and mystery, that you must master - or be destroyed. It takes cunning, it takes decisiveness, it takes ambition, (more)
Does Link from TheLegendofZelda ever speak?
A Japanese grown up with Zelda games

Adding to what people already answered, I believe his name "Link" originally came from the idea which the developer want him to be a link between players and Hyrule. I am not sure if it was Miyamoto who said that, but whoever that was, he wanted players to feel as they are Link and to be in the Hyrule. Actually Link is not a mute. There are many scenes that he explains things he had done, seen, or heard in gesture and get reactions from people, but we as players just never hear or see the exact word choice he made to do so. We just have to imagine. I think that is the whole point of Link. By controlling him, players are constantly forced to imagine. What is he saying? in what tone? in what intention? How would I say it if I was him... By such imagination we are “linked” into the world in ga (more)
I've played every non CDi Zelda game.

What is the objective of Legend of Zelda? Well, that would depend on the game. In the original The Legend of Zelda, your tasks are to recover all the broken pieces of the Triforce, kiil the evil overlord Ganon, and save the princess Zelda. In Zelda 2: Link's Adventure, you must return magical gems to their pillers (handily placed at the end of dungeons) in order wake up a princess Zelda from a previous generation (an aunt, great aunt or so to Zelda 1’s princess). Oh, and monsters are after your blood to reincarnate Ganon. In A Link to the Past, you must save the seven maidens (and princess Zelda) who were captured and ensorcelled by an agent of Ganon's. But first you must complete three dungeons and recover the lost Master Sword. In Link's Awakening, you are stranded on an island, and to escap (more)
